Chapter 5: Refuting the Senses and Objects, Refuting the Senses and Objects Next, as mentioned above, the senses, objects, etc. will be extensively refuted later. I will now explain.
The senses are the basis for distinguishing objects. Before refuting the senses, one should first eliminate their objects. Once the objects are eliminated, the senses will also disappear.
KÄpila says:
Things like pots and clothes are only composed of form, etc., and the substance of what the senses perceive truly exists.
In order to refute this view, a verse is spoken:
Among the parts of a pot, only form can be seen;
If the whole pot can be seen, how can one understand the truth?
The treatise states:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

Your school itself says that the various faculties such as the eyes each take their own objects and do not mix up with each other. The eyes only see form, while a vase has four elements. How can it be that when one sees form one completely sees the substance of the vase?
This shows that the substance of the vase is not seen by the eyes, because it is not only form, just like sound and so forth.
Isn't the substance of the vase also form?
I do not say that the substance of the vase is only not form, but only that the substance of the vase is not only form, so the reason you give is not fallacious.
Since you are already in disagreement with what is right before your eyes, how can we believe what you say about realizing the truth?
Just as the eyes only see form and not the vase, so it is with smell and so forth.
Therefore the next verse says:
Those with superior wisdom, according to the meaning stated above,
Should refute all categories of smell, taste, and touch.
The treatise says:

The objects of the faculties of nose, tongue, and body are each different. The meaning of completely taking the substance of the vase is also not established, because the vase is not the object taken by the three faculties.
Each inference should be understood as before. Since sound is not eternal, it is not mentioned here. Sound should be the same as form and so forth.

In this way, all pots, clothes, carts, and so forth are not objects perceived by the sense faculties. The determinate mental consciousness does not necessarily perceive external objects, but must follow the sense faculties.
Since pots and so forth are not objects of the sense faculties, the mind should also be the same.
If it were not so, then even blind and deaf people would be able to perceive external objects such as form.
In this way, pots and so forth are not within the scope of the sense faculties, but are all arisen from the mind's own discrimination.

If it is said that because pots and so forth are not different in substance from form and so forth, the sense faculties such as the eyes also perceive pots and so forth just as they perceive their own objects, therefore the sense faculties can also gradually perceive objects such as pots.

If that were so, then pots and so forth would be within the scope of all the sense faculties, contradicting the fact that each sense faculty perceives its own objects, or the substance of a single pot would become multiple.
Perhaps the various faculties do not apprehend vases, etc., because only form, etc., are the substance of the faculties and objects.
Since form, etc., individually are not vases, how, when combined, do they form the real substance of a vase?

If it is said that vases, etc., are formed by the combination of many parts, and when one part is seen it is said that one sees the vase, etc., just as when one sees a part of a city it is also called seeing the city,
this is also not so, because a city is not real. The substance of a city is a conceptual fiction formed by the combination of many parts. When one part is seen, it is not called seeing the whole.
If vases, etc., are like this, they are conceptual fictions, not real. How can you insist that they are real and can be seen?
Moreover, as for saying that when one part is seen it can be seen, this principle is not so. Therefore the next verse says:
If one only sees the color of a vase and says one sees the vase,
since one does not see smell, etc., one should be called not seeing the vase.
The treatise states:

If a composite whole is said to be perceived by a part of it, then a pot should be said to be seen when its color is seen, since color is a part of the pot. The other parts such as smell, etc., are not seen, so it should be said that the pot is not seen, since the majority of its parts are not seen. It should not be said that color is the most important part of the pot, since it is only a part of the pot, just like smell, etc.
Since color, etc., are neither the most important nor the least important parts of the pot, the pot should be said to be invisible, since it is a part of smell, etc.

The world gives names to things either according to the majority of their parts or according to their most important part. Color is totally absent in smell, etc., but smell, etc., are present in color. Therefore, pots, etc., should be said to be invisible, since they are a part of smell, etc.
Then external color should also not be real, since it is a visible nature that is a part of the invisible pot, clothing, etc., just like smell, etc.
How can it be said that the color of a pot is invisible, since the world commonly knows that the color of a pot is visible?

The visible forms that are known in the world are said to be visible only because they are transformations of one's own mind. They are not external real forms. Now, in order to refute the existence of real forms outside the mind, it is said that they are not visible. This does not contradict the fact that invisible dharmas do not exist.
It should not be said.
Why is this?
Because the visible does not exist, it is called invisible. How can something that is completely nonexistent be spoken of?
Visible dharmas, because they have substance, can be spoken of for others.
This is also not so.
Dharmas without substance are also the cause of speech. If it were not so, the word invisible would not exist.
Moreover, seeing form does not benefit at all. Why is form said to be visible?
It is not invisible.
Why is this?

It is not because of the ability to see or the inability to see that form has differences. How can it be said that form is visible because of seeing, and not said to be invisible because of not seeing?

Just as the color on the top of a pot is visible, so the pot is said to be visible. The fragrance, etc., on the pot are not visible, so the pot should also be said to be invisible, because the reasoning is the same.
Moreover, when the eye sees, it is said that form is visible. When the eye does not see, it should also be said that form is invisible, because the reasoning is the same.
Since the pot and form both have the meaning of being visible and invisible, why is it now only refuted that they are visible and established that they are invisible?
Because the attachment to visibility is stopped, it is said to be invisible, not establishing the pot or form as invisible.
Moreover, form is also not entirely visible. How can the seeing of the pot be due to form?
Why is this so?
Therefore, the next verse says:
Obstructed forms are not entirely visible,
Because they are divided by their parts and the space in between.
The treatise says:
There is obstructed form that is not entirely visible, as when one part is obstructed by another part, as when a wall, etc., obstructs.
Although one sees a part of all forms, one does not see the rest, and therefore they should be called invisible like a pot.
Among the parts, this part is not superior, and the other parts are more numerous. It should be called invisible according to the majority.

Coarse form gradually becomes smaller until it reaches the ultimate atom. It is always composed of many parts. If it reaches the ultimate atom, it is not the object of the material faculties. Therefore all forms are invisible.
Isn't it the case that the outer surface of the ultimate atom is spread out without obstruction, and it abides side by side with others, all visible?

The general characteristics of many atoms are provisional and not real. The specific characteristics of each individual atom are not the objects of the material faculties. The surface of an obstructed ultimate atom has this and that. How can it be established that the substance of form really exists and is entirely visible?
Although the general characteristics of all ultimate atoms are provisional, each individual atom abiding separately really cannot be seen.

However, the extremely subtle particles combine and assist each other, and cannot be analyzed. The front and back sides have each other, therefore each subtle particle has a real substance, and can be seen in its entirety.
This is also not so.
Therefore, the next verse says:
The existence or non-existence of parts in the subtle particle, should be carefully considered;
Citing non-completion as evidence, the meaning will ultimately not be established.
The treatise says:

Because the subtle particle also combines with other things, it should be like coarse things having parts and being provisional. In the chapter on refuting permanence, it has already been explained that the subtle particle has parts and is not real.
Since each subtle particle cannot be seen, how can the combination and assistance be seen?
If, when assisting each other, they do not abandon their original characteristics, they should not assist each other;

If they abandon their original characteristics, they should not be subtle particles, because when assisting each other, if they are as subtle as originally, they should have no assisting power and should not be seen.
If they transform into coarseness, they should not be subtle particles, and should be provisional and not real.

When carefully considering the extreme subtlety of form, it is due to obstruction that it has parts and is not real, and cannot be entirely seen. Therefore, it cannot be used as evidence to prove that all form is real and can be seen.

Just as form, due to the previously explained principles, has parts and is not real and is not the object of the form sense faculty, in the same way, all phenomena with resistance are composed of many and are not the objects of the form sense faculty.
In order to illustrate this meaning, another verse is spoken:
All phenomena with resistance are composed of many parts.
The treatise states:
All phenomena with resistance, when analyzed by wisdom, all have many parts that rely on each other to establish themselves. When the analysis is not yet complete, they are always like coarse things.

The composition of many parts is provisional and not real. When the analysis is complete, they return to emptiness, just like the ultimate non-existence that transcends the objects of the form sense faculty.

All that can be seen is composed of many, which is commonly known in the world to be provisional and not real. The subtle parts are obstructed and cannot be entirely seen. The characteristics of extreme subtlety are mutually supportive and not established.
All obstructed objects can be analyzed. When not yet exhausted, returning to emptiness is provisional. Therefore, there is absolutely no real color that can be seen, heard, smelled, tasted, etc.
Since the color that is explained is not the object of the faculties, the explainer is also like this.
Therefore, the next verse says:
Speech and words are also like this, therefore not grasped by the faculties.
The treatise says:

All sounds and speech that are heard are gradually analyzed down to a single word. This also has subtle parts like before. They are further gradually analyzed down to the most subtle particles. This is not what is heard, but still has subtle parts. They are further gradually analyzed until there is absolutely nothing.
As long as the analysis is not yet exhausted, it is obstructed, and there are always subtle parts. This is provisional and not real.

Moreover, the subtle parts of sound are arranged before and after, not continuing with each other. The essence has no meaning of combination, is not a real expression, and is not really audible. The principle is clear.
Therefore, it is said separately that if the subtle parts of sound arise simultaneously, not sequentially, they are established like the subtle parts of form.
Words such as sara and rasa can be heard simultaneously, and their meanings should be no different.
Thus, it has been refuted that the five sense objects such as form exist as real entities and are perceived by the sense faculties of form.
Next, some say:
The shape of form is what the eyes see.
Now, we should ask:ğŸ”½Is this shape of form separate from the manifest color?
Or is it the same as the manifest color?
If it is separate from the manifest color, it should not be seen by the eyes, because it is separate from blue and so forth, like sound and so forth.
If it is the same as the manifest color, it should also not be seen by the eyes, just like the manifest color, as has been extensively discussed previously.
Moreover, it is said in a verse:
Although manifest color has shape, how does one apprehend the shape of color?
The treatise states:
If shape exists separately from manifest color, how does one apprehend shape based on the manifest color?
Just as there is pleasure in sound, etc., apart from manifest form, when one's own faculties grasp them, they do not rely on manifest form.

However, when one grasps shape while relying on manifest form, it is like seeing fire from a distance and knowing its general characteristic of heat. Therefore shape color must definitely not be grasped by the form faculty, or else it must not be seen by the eye.
If someone else says:

If one grasps shape without relying on blue, etc., one should refute it in this way. The discrimination of shape in an unmoving manifest form must be preceded by the discrimination of the form faculty's object. Because it takes shape as its object.

All that takes shape as its object must be preceded by the discrimination of the form faculty's object, just as the discrimination of shape in a whirling firebrand, or the discrimination of shape in the dark.
Some say:
The substance of shape and manifest form are each separate, because their discrimination is different, like smell, taste, etc.
It is commonly seen in the world that length, etc., and blue, etc., are each discriminated differently.
If so, then the various derivative form of the world, because their discrimination is different from gold, silver, etc., should have separate substances.
Since the reason is not definite, how can the meaning of the thesis be established?
Or, how does one grasp shape and color? If shape really exists and is seen by the eyes, how does one grasp shape based on touch?
One does not see blue, etc., grasped based on touch.
Since shape can be known based on touch, it should be like roughness, etc., and not seen by the eyes.
If this reason is said to definitely depend on touch to know shape, one should not know shape based on visible form.
If it is said that shape is definitely known based on touch, one should also know shape based on touching wind, water, etc.
This objection is unreasonable.
My meaning only says that shape can be known based on touch, and therefore it is not seen by the eyes;
I do not say that knowing shape is definitely based on touch.
If so, visible form is also known based on touch, and therefore it should not be seen, just as one knows the color of fire, etc., based on touching it.
This must be known by being separated by the distinctions of length, etc., therefore the reason given does not have the fault of being indefinite.
Why is this so?

If one relies on touch to distinguish blue and so forth, it must be inferred knowledge, not the common characteristic of blue and so forth seen by the eye. This is certainly obstructed by distinctions such as long and so forth. It cannot be criticized by saying that it is not directly based on touch.
Shape should also be like this, because shape is not determined in relation to touch. Because manifestation is determined, it is not similar.
In this way, separation from manifestation and existence of shape has already been refuted.
Manifestation also does not exist, therefore the next verse says:
If manifestation grasps manifest color, why not by the body?
The treatise says:

If shape is precisely the manifest color such as blue and so forth, then manifest color should be grasped by the body like shape. In that case, the body's contact should know manifest color, because it is precisely shape, just like the color of shape.
The body's contact knows shape but does not know its manifestation, therefore one should know that manifest color is not precisely shape.
This means that shape is not precisely manifest color, because the knowledge is not the same, just like pleasant sounds.
If shape is neither identical with nor different from manifestation, it should be like a chariot, etc., and its substance is not real.
If the substance of shape is real, like the color blue, etc., it should be either identical with or different from manifest color.
Moreover, the various kinds of shape have no separate atoms, because each atom has no length, etc.

Apart from manifest atoms, there is no length, etc. The intrinsic nature of atoms is difficult to understand. Since the size of manifest atoms is not separate, how can there be real shape apart from manifestation?
It cannot be said that each atom has the characteristics of length, etc., because length, etc., like gross substance, can be analyzed. What is meant by atom?
Moreover, it is commonly accepted that the size of all atoms is without distinction. Now, if it is said that atoms have the characteristics of length, etc., this contradicts one's own tenets.
Because your school accepts that the size of atoms is without distinction, you should also believe that there is no shape apart from manifestation.

If you say that although the atoms do not have length, etc., they accumulate and grow to have the form of length, etc., then this shows that the atoms accumulate to form length, etc., so why is it necessary to posit separately atoms with the form of length, etc.?

Moreover, length, etc., is not like blue, etc., in that when it is analyzed to the utmost, its original characteristics still remain. Therefore length, etc., is not the object of the material faculties, because it has no real substance, just like a flower in the sky.ğŸ”½If the atoms are not really long, etc., how can they accumulate to form length, etc.?
You admit that the substance of the atoms is not gross, so how can they accumulate to form the gross?
Therefore length, etc., does not really exist, but is merely formed by the accumulation of blue, etc.
Next, in the SÄá¹ƒkhya school, apart from form, etc., they posit real universals, particularities, etc., which by the power of their support, form, etc., become objects of the material faculties.
This is also not so.
It was previously said that form, etc., is not grasped by the material faculties, so they are also not objects of the material faculties.
Some in that school say:

The real substance, etc., must be seen only when the gross qualities and the color qualities combine. If there were no two qualities, it would be like the atoms and the wind in space. Although they exist, they are not seen.
This is also not so.
The gross, like length, etc., when analyzed, returns to nonexistence.
Color cannot be seen, as explained above. How can one see the real substance, etc., based on this?
There is another explanation:

The real substance, etc., that are the basis must be seen because of the color that is the dependent. It is like hot water, where the color of fire is covered by the water. Although the real substance of fire exists, it cannot be seen.

In that treatise, there is a refutation of this explanation. When the blue and other colored dyes dye white cloth, the white color is not seen. It should not be seen. One cannot say that by seeing the colored dye, one sees the basis of the dye.
The real substance of the basis of the dye is combined with the cloth, so the cloth can also be seen.
Why is this?
Since the two real substances of water and fire are combined, by seeing the color of water, one sees the water. It should also be by this that one sees the real substance of fire.
Both of these masters' positions are unreasonable. First, using one of their arguments, we refute their position.
In order to refute their attachment, we further state a verse:
The cause of form apart from form should not be seen by the eye;
Since the natures of the two dharmas are different, why are they not separately observed?
The treatise says:
The real basis of form is called the cause of form. In this way, if the cause of form is apart from blue, etc., it should be like taste, etc., and not seen by the eye.
If the nature of form and the cause of form are different, like blue, yellow, etc., they should be separately observed.
Since the real, apart from form, cannot be separately observed, it should be like the nature of form itself, without a separate reality.
The real and form can also be separately observed, like the separate understanding of seeing blue and yellow.
Thus, these two understandings are not the consciousness of the form faculty, because they arise from a combination of the unreal mind, just as the unreal mind.
Next, the VaiÅ›eá¹£ikas may say this:
If you say that form really exists but that aggregated form does not really exist and therefore cannot be seen, then you would commit the error of maintaining that many forms exist in one place.
We say that like things do not necessarily occupy the same place, and therefore there is only one form in one place. We do not commit this error.
This is not so.
If form really exists, it cannot be seen, because it has no parts, just like space, etc.
This reason is not conclusive, because such things as the nature of form also have no parts and yet can be seen.
How do you know that the nature of form exists apart from the substance of form?
Moreover, how do you know that the nature of form can be seen?
In order to refute this opinion, we say that apart from form there is a cause of form, etc.
Here the nature of form is said to be the cause of form, because the knowledge of form and the word form arise in dependence on it.
If the nature of form is different from the substance of form, is unitary, and is all-pervading, it should be visible apart from blue, etc., and apart from the place of blue, etc.
Since it cannot be seen, the nature of form definitely should not be seen by the eyes.
Some say:
If one grasps the nature of form as having a pervasive substance, one may incur this fault;
I say that the nature of form follows its own basis, each being different, and there is no such fault.
This is also not so.

If the nature of form and so forth follows its own basis and the substance is not the same, then in a place without blue, blue would suddenly arise, and in a place with blue, blue would suddenly cease.
At that time, the nature of form and the form that is its basis would be in different places, and each should be established separately.
But you do not accept this, so how can there be no fault?
If one says that the nature of form has the ability to move and transform to another place or newly arise, then this nature is not unitary and not permanent.
Since one accepts it as unitary and permanent, its substance should be pervasive, and one would return to the previous fault.
It should also be visible apart from blue and so forth;
Since it cannot be seen, it should not be the object of the eyes.
Aren't other dharmas in the middle not seen because there is no cause for understanding them?
What is called the cause for understanding?
It is the distinctions of shape and size.
If that is so, then the nature of form should not be seen, because the forms that are its supports have no shape or size.
Moreover, this nature of form should not be seen by the eyes, because its substance is all-pervading, like the nature of sound and so forth.
If the substance of form and the nature of form are different, they should be able to be observed separately, like blue and yellow, etc.
However, these two kinds cannot be separately observed as form and its nature, therefore there is no difference.

It cannot be said that when seeing, one does not understand that this is form and this is the nature, and the two appearances are different, because the difference in the appearances of form and its nature should be like blue and yellow, because they give rise to similar seeing of themselves as conditions.
Since the seeing is the same, what is seen should be the same. Therefore, apart from form, there is no separate nature of form.
Since there is no nature of form apart from form that can be seen, how is the reason for inference not indeterminate?
The other sounds, natures, etc., should be investigated one by one according to the appropriate method, just as they were refuted above.
Next, in the SÄá¹ƒkhya school, it is said:
Earth, water, and fire have both form and touch, and are all perceived by both the eye and the body faculties.
It is commonly accepted in the world that the three great elements such as earth, etc., are seen by the eye and felt by the body.
Wind is only perceived by the body, because it has no form.
This is also not so.
The perception by the eye has already been refuted, and the perception by the body will be refuted next.
If we follow what is commonly accepted in the world, the body can only perceive the quality of touch, not anything else.
Why is this so?
Therefore, the next verse says:
The body perceives solidity, etc., and establishes the names of earth, etc.
Therefore, it only speaks of the distinctions of earth, etc., within touch.
The treatise states:

The body senses solidity, humidity, heat, and motion in the world, and then people establish earth, water, fire, and wind. Therefore only touch is called earth, etc., and apart from touch there are no separate real entities such as earth, etc. that are the supports.
The meaning of this is that the four real entities such as earth, etc. are not apart from touch, because they are sensed by the body, just like the touch of solidity, etc.
If one grasps the idea that earth, etc. are not included in touch, then they should not be sensed by the body, just like taste, etc.
If one establishes the names earth, etc. for solidity, etc., then there is nothing to dispute, because their substance is not separate.
If one establishes that earth, etc. are the supports of touch, but are not identical with solidity, etc., then this contradicts the above inference.
The first half of the verse clarifies that the specific characteristics of the great elements such as earth, etc. are sensed by the body and are included in touch.
The second half clarifies that the common characteristics of those earth, etc. are not included in touch and are not sensed by the body, but are only known by the discriminating mental consciousness.
The specific and common characteristics of form, etc. should be understood in the same way, according to the circumstances.
Moreover, when the great elements such as earth are burned, no different characteristics arise, so they are not objects of the senses, like a burned pot, etc.
In the state of maturity, different characteristics arise, such as the color red, etc.
These different characteristics are included in the category of qualities, and apart from these, no real category of substance with different characteristics arises.
How can it be said that apart from qualities, there is a real category of earth, etc. that is perceived by the body sense faculty?
In order to illustrate this meaning, another verse is spoken:
When a pot is seen arising, no different qualities are seen.
The substance arises as it is seen, so there is no real nature at all.
The treatise states:

When pots, etc. are burned, qualities such as the color red arise, and they are seen to be different from before. Apart from this, there is no real substance of a pot in the category of substance that arises differently from the unburned state.
If the real category of substance such as a pot has a separate substance, it should have different characteristics arising, like the category of qualities.

The states of burning and being burned, as well as the combination of them, do not have the characteristics of real categories that arise separately. They should be like space and so forth, not having the nature of real existence. They are also not the objects perceived by the physical sense faculties, but are only known by the discriminating conceptual consciousness. They are included in the conventional truth, and are provisional, not real.
Next, the coarse and obvious object-characteristics grasped by non-Buddhists and other vehicles have been briefly refuted by me.
Now I will comprehensively refute all the object-characteristics imagined by non-Buddhists and other vehicles.
It is said that those object-characteristics are roughly of two kinds:
One is obstructive, the other is non-obstructive.
Obstructive objects can all be analyzed, because they are obstructive, like a house, like a forest.
Analysis leads to emptiness, or to an infinite regress. Therefore, they cannot be grasped as truly existent.
Non-obstructive objects also do not truly exist, because they are non-obstructive, like space flowers.
Moreover, the grasped objects are roughly of two kinds:
One is conditioned, the other is unconditioned.
Because conditioned dharmas are born from conditions, they are like magical creations and do not really exist.
Unconditioned dharmas also do not really exist, because they are devoid of birth, like the horns of a tortoise.

Also, the objects grasped as real have many natures in accordance with various categories of dharmas. If they really exist, they must contradict one another. Furthermore, if you analyze and return to emptiness, there is the error of infinite regress.
Also, the grasped form must not be real form, because it is an object of knowledge, just like sound, etc.
Extensively, it is said that the grasped dharmas must not be real dharmas, because they are objects of knowledge, just like form, etc.
For this reason, all that is grasped, whether existent or nonexistent, is not real.

The wise should correctly understand that objects such as existence and nonexistence are all established by means of names and characteristics based on the conventional, and are not true ultimate reality.
Next, having refuted the objects, he again refutes the sense organs.
First he refutes the other vehicles, and therefore he speaks a verse:
The eyes and so forth are all derived from the four great elements. Why does the eye see and not the others?
The treatise says:

The five faculties such as the eyes are all pure form derived from the four great elements as their intrinsic nature. Therefore the sutra says, The pure form derived from the four great elements is called the faculties such as the eyes.
This is conventional language, not ultimate truth.
If one grasps it as real, its meaning is not established.
Why is this?
How can it be that among the derived forms, the function of seeing belongs only to the eyes and not to the others?

Have you not seen in the world that two dharmas that are similar in arising give rise to functions that are mutually different? How can it be that the faculties each serve as the basis for their own consciousness?
This effect is different, not different in characteristics. Since the characteristics are no different, how can the effects be different?
Because the functions are different, the effects are not the same.

It is seen in the world that functions differ while the characteristics are the same. For example, various medicinal herbs have different functions of benefiting or harming, but the same characteristics of solidity and so forth.
Since the characteristics are the same, the functions should not be different.

Moreover, the faculties should be the great elements themselves. The function of producing consciousness is called the eye faculty, etc., just as the different functions of solidity, etc. are given the names of various herbs.
This is not so.
Because the substance of characteristics and functions is the same, but the names are different.
Because the functions of seeing, etc. are different, it is evident that the characteristics of the eye, etc. are different. There is no separate function.

Based on the absence of separate characteristics, since the functions are not the same, the characteristics must be different. Therefore, it is established that there is a separate existence apart from the great elements.
If that is so, since the functions of herbs are also not the same, there should also be a separate substance apart from the great elements.
What contradiction is there in allowing a separate substance?
If it is like seeing, etc., which are completely separate from the great elements, the meaning may be without contradiction;
but they are not completely separate. How can there be no contradiction?
If it is said that although the natures and categories of the eye, etc. are the same, there are differences in characteristics, then it contradicts one's own school.
Your school holds that the nature and species of a dharma are its substance and characteristics. Since nature and species are the same, how can characteristics be different?
One substance cannot have two different characteristics, same and different, both of which are unreal, just as one color does not have the two different characteristics of blue and yellow.

If the nature of one dharma can be divided into two characteristics, then each of these can be further divided, and so on, until you arrive at emptiness or infinity, and it is not always a real existent.
Also, by what are the substance and differences of the organs of sight, etc., established?
They are established by the causes of seeing, etc.
Are not the same great elements used as causes for seeing, etc.? How can there be differences?

If the differences of seeing, etc., are due to differences in the great elements that produce them, then the consciousnesses, such as visual consciousness, etc., should be produced by these different great elements, and what need is there for the organs of sight, etc.?
The great elements are not the only cause of seeing, etc., so how can it be said that because they are not different, seeing, etc., are not different?

What is the reason for this? It is good and bad karma. This karma arises through the gradual differences of various conditions such as craving, pleasure, and views. Because of this karma, there are differences in views, etc.
If many full karmas separately produce views, etc., the meaning is acceptable.
If a single karma generally produces a single body, how can there be differences?

Moreover, the bodily karma of the form realm is undifferentiated. It is only attracted by a single karma that is disgusted with taste, etc. The various faculties of that realm should be undifferentiated.

If it is said that a single karma has many functions, therefore the body and faculties that it produces are different, then karma and function are both activities. How can a single activity have many activities?

It is not said that a single activity again has many activities. It is only said that a single substance has many functions. Because of these functions, many fruits are produced, just like the homogeneous eye.
Although the substance is one, it can produce consciousness and produce its own kind. The hypothetical explanation is acceptable, but how is it really so?
One is precisely many, because the principle contradicts itself.
If you admit that one action has many powers and produces many organs, why not admit that action produces only one organ and that many consciousnesses are born?
What benefit is there in such a refutation?
Also, when one organ is damaged or benefited, the other organs should be damaged or benefited in the same way.
Also, if one organ is present, the body should be ugly. I do not refute you and allow only one organ, but I want to refute your claim that one action has many uses.
Also, by the power of action, there is no simultaneous damage or benefit to the organs, just as in hell, although fierce fires burn the body, the organs are not destroyed.
Also, because the organs are present, the body is well-proportioned, just as a blind person is not ugly.
Also, if one action can produce many results, and the production of different consciousnesses proves the existence of different organs, then such an inference should not be established.

The existence of this and the existence of that, the non-existence of this and the non-existence of that, can only establish different powers, and cannot prove the existence of different substantial forms.
Also, why canâ€™t the specific power of this action produce the various consciousnesses?
When the various consciousnesses are born, action has already ceased and therefore cannot have the function of producing them. If this is so, then the eye, etc., should not be born from that action.
If the perfuming that is attracted by action still exists and can produce the eye, etc., why canâ€™t the various consciousnesses be born from the perfuming that is attracted by action?
This is not so.

When one is born in the formless realms, the five consciousnesses such as visual consciousness should also be active, because the substance of consciousness exists. The establishment of material organs is not subject to this error.
When one is born in the formless realms, the four great material elements do not exist, and therefore derived matter also does not exist. On what is the birth of beings there based?
Because they are free from craving for form.
It is precisely because of this cause that the seeds of consciousness are damaged, and therefore the five consciousnesses such as visual consciousness are not born there.
This is not so.
It is not the case that because one is free from craving for objects, the seeds of consciousness that grasp those objects are also damaged.

The consciousness that has them as objects will never arise again in those who have already attained freedom from desire in the realm of desire or in those who have attained freedom from desire in the three realms.

If you say that consciousness can arise because the support is projected by action of the same realm, then when a person is born in the realm of form, he should not be able to have consciousness with objects in the realm of desire. If this is so, you should say that consciousness does not arise because there is no object when one is born in the formless realm.
Why does it not arise with objects of lower stages as objects?
If you say that it does not arise with them as objects because one is already free from desire for them, this has already been explained.
What was the explanation?
It was said that one born in a higher stage should not be able to have consciousness with objects in a lower stage.

If the five consciousnesses are born from the seeds of action, then the consciousnesses should not be helped or harmed by the presence of the organs, because the organs are not the support of the seeds of action.
Why is this?
The seeds of action do not use the organs as a support, and consciousness does not change because the organs change.
Because the present consciousness is helped or harmed, the seeds of action are also helped or harmed.
Why is this?

In the world, there is presently the mind and its objects, which are the consciousness that falsely discriminates, able to cause other dharmas to be benefited or harmed. It is like the mind in a dream falsely thinking of the mind and so forth.
If one does not realize the benefit or harm of the faculties, the consciousness that relies on them should have no benefit or harm. In this case, there must be subtle awareness and feeling.
There are endless questions and answers of this kind, but fearing the proliferation of words, we should stop here for now.

The nature and characteristics of dharmas are subtle and profound, extremely difficult for those with shallow understanding to comprehend. For now, we should follow worldly convention and speak of the existence of the faculties, not immediately investigating and seeking to accord with the true meaning.
Therefore, the next verse says:
Therefore, the fruits of karma are inconceivable, truly spoken by the Sage.
The treatise says:

The meaning of this verse is that the fruits of karma, such as the eyes, are inconceivable. Only the TathÄgata can deeply understand them, not by the power of the knowledge of others with shallow understanding. One should follow the world and speak of them as existing, not immediately investigating and seeking to accord with their truth.
The true nature of dharmas is known through inner realization and is not the domain of worldly discursive thought.
If one grasps it as truly existent, it is definitely not so.
Why is this?
Because it contradicts inferential cognition.ğŸ”½The eyes are not seen, like the ear faculty and so forth.
The ears are also not heard, like the eye faculty and so forth.ğŸ”½The nose cannot smell, like the tongue faculty and so forth.
The tongue cannot taste, like the nose faculty and so forth.
The body cannot sense, like the faculties above.
All are due to the nature of derivative form, or the primary elements, or the fruits of karma.
Moreover, the faculties such as the eyes are all obstructed, so they can be analyzed and reduced to emptiness or an infinite regress. Therefore, one should not grasp them as truly existent.
They are merely one's own mind, falsely appearing through the power of causes and conditions, like magical creations and so forth, conventionally existent but ultimately non-existent.
Next, the SÄá¹ƒkhya non-Buddhist school says:
The objects of form, etc., are all grasped by two faculties, namely, the seeing by the eye, etc., and the knowing by the internal consciousness.
Now we must carefully examine whether seeing and knowing are simultaneous with regard to an object,
or whether there is a sequence of first and last.
Even if you admit a sequence of first and last, which is first and which is last?
It is unreasonable for them to be simultaneous.
Why is this?
Therefore the next verse says,
Because knowledge has no object yet, knowledge is not prior to seeing.
If it comes after, knowledge is useless.
If simultaneous, seeing has no use.
The treatise says:

Seeing is the object of knowledge, and knowledge arises in accordance with seeing. If there is no seeing, knowledge definitely does not arise. It is like a person born blind who has no knowledge of form. Therefore the arising of knowledge is definitely not prior to seeing.
If it comes after seeing, knowledge is useless. Since seeing has already understood form, what further use is there for knowledge?
In your school, the arising of dharmas must be for my use, not merely arising spontaneously in accordance with causes.
If it is necessary to generate cognition again after seeing has already occurred, then one object would be clearly cognized endlessly.

If the two occur simultaneously, then seeing would be useless, and the two dharmas would both exist without cause and effect, like the two horns of an ox, like pain and pleasure, etc. You should not allow that seeing is the cause of cognition.
If cognition knows an object without arising from seeing, then blind and deaf people should clearly perceive objects.
Also, there should not be blind and deaf people, because they all clearly perceive forms, etc.
Also, you should not establish the five faculties of sentient beings, because the mind alone can clearly perceive forms, etc.
Next, some establish that the eye and ear perceive objects only when they come together with them.
That principle is not so.
Therefore, the next verse says:
If the eye travels to the object, then seeing distant forms should be slow.
Why does it not also clearly illuminate extremely distant and near forms?
The treatise says:ğŸ”½The eye refers to the light of the eye, because it is the function of the eye.
Because it is not separate from the eye, it is also called the eye.
If this light of the eye travels to the place of form, why is the seen distant form not delayed?
How is it that the moon and the nearby forms are seen simultaneously without delay when one looks up?
We have never seen in the world any moving thing that arrives simultaneously at distant and nearby places. For this reason, an inference should be established.
The seeing of distant form does not reach distant form, because there is no difference in the time of seeing nearby form, just as in the seeing of nearby form.
The seeing of nearby form does not reach nearby form, because there is no difference in the time of seeing distant form, just as in the seeing of distant form.

Moreover, if the light of the eye travels to form in order to see it, then the most distant and nearby forms should be seen clearly, and the seeing should be no different from that of what is neither distant nor nearby.
Since there is a difference, therefore the eye does not reach its object.

The nose and other sense organs do not have this difference of distance and clarity in smell, taste, and touch. For this reason, we infer that the eye does not reach its object, because there is a difference in function regarding distant and nearby objects, just like a magnet.
Moreover, if the eye goes to the form first and then sees it, or does not see it, both are unreasonable.
Therefore, the next verse says:
If one goes after seeing, the going is useless;
If one goes without seeing, one should not definitely want to see.
The treatise says:
Originally, one goes to the object in order to see form. If the form has already been seen, what is the use of going again?
If one goes after seeing, this also contradicts the previous assertion that the eye and ear know only when they come into contact with the object.
One cannot say that one goes without seeing. How can one who is blind and has no guide go in a certain direction?
Just as a blind person cannot definitely reach the destination he wants to go to, this is also the case.
If one goes without seeing, one should not have a fixed destination, or one might stop in the middle upon encountering form.
One who goes with a fixed destination in mind may either achieve his goal or stop midway due to exhaustion of strength.
Since these two kinds of reasons are both unreasonable, and there is no third possibility, therefore it is not the case that the object and sense faculty come into contact.
Next, there is another explanation:
The eye faculty does not come into contact with visible forms.
This is also unreasonable.
Therefore, the next verse says:
If one can see without going, one should see all forms;
Since the eye has no movement, there is no far or near, and no obstruction.
The treatise says:
The essence of non-contact does not exist, because there is no difference in characteristics. One should see all or not see at all.
Why is this?
Because there is no difference in conditions.
The difference in dharmas that arise from conditions is not established. Aren't all forms not seen due to distance or obstruction?
Since the eye does not move, what is far and what is obstructed that prevents seeing?

If one sees visible forms without the eye coming into contact with them, there should be no difference between far and near, obstructed and unobstructed, because the cause of non-contact is without difference.
The principle of seeing and not seeing cannot be established.
Moreover, the name extremely far does not have a real essence. How can it obstruct and prevent seeing from arising?
The dharmas between the two are not called distant, because they do not obstruct the function of seeing.
If you maintain that the dharmas between the two are called distant because they obstruct the function of seeing, then the distant obstruction should be the same as the near obstruction.

The same error is committed in maintaining that the eye goes to visible forms. That is, extreme distance is not a real entity, etc. If you maintain that the eye is permanent and goes to visible forms, you commit the error of real existence.
Why is this?
If you maintain that the eye is impermanent and goes to visible forms, you can say that its power is exhausted and it does not reach distant places.
If you maintain that the eye always functions and is not subject to change and goes to visible forms, the error is the same as the previous one.
Both functioning and not functioning commit errors, and therefore the eye sees visible forms neither by functioning nor by not functioning.
Isnâ€™t it that light assists the eye in seeing, and because light is obstructed, one does not see?
When one looks at a distant color in a jewel or lamp in the night, since it is separated from darkness by an obstruction, one should not be able to see it.
If you say that although the eye faculty does not reach visible forms, it is like a magnet that functions at a distance,
This is also unreasonable, because of doubts and difficulties.
What doubts and difficulties are commonly seen in the world?
This is also unreasonable, because the real and the conventional are different.
The world sees the conventional, which you hold to be real.
The world also does not know that what is not combined is seen. How can it be said to be the same as a magnet?
Although the previous verses refute the eye, they also refute the ear, because the meaning is the same.
If the ear faculty knows objects by combining with them, one should not hear far and near at the same time.
Since the sound comes from the substance and has far and near, it should not arrive at the ear faculty at the same moment.
The ear has no light and should not reach the object.
Even if it is allowed to reach the object, the error is the same as the eye faculty.
Moreover, it is also unreasonable for the sound to come from the substance and enter the ear to be heard.
The sound of bells and drums is presently not separate from the substance, because it can be heard from a distance.
If the ear and sound are grasped without hearing, it should be like smell, etc., and not distinguish directions.
If the ear does not contact sound and yet grasps it, then it should hear everything near and far, because the non-contacting substance has no distinction.
Or it should be that none can be heard.
Therefore, whether the ear faculty contacts sound or not, it actually grasps its own object, and both are untenable.
Next, if one grasps that the eye faculty can see form, then it should see its own nature.
Why is this?
Therefore, the next verse says:
The substance, characteristics, and function of dharmas must be the same before and after;
How is it that this eye faculty does not see the nature of the eye?
The treatise says:
The substance, characteristics, and function of dharmas must be the same before and after, because they are mutually related and have no separate nature.
If the eye can see, it should be like my thought, always taking seeing as its substance.
Then the eye faculty would not be facing an object, but it should always be able to see, just as when facing an object.
At that time, form does not exist, but there is the function of seeing, which should take the substance of the eye as what is observed.
If the eye cannot see when there is no form, it should also be unable to see when there is form.
Moreover, if the eye faculty has seeing as its essence, it should be able to see itself, just like light. This contradicts your own tenet that the sense faculties are not objects of their own kind.
If it cannot see itself, it should not be able to see others, just like a completely blind person who sees nothing at all.

Moreover, your school says that the characteristics and functions of dharmas such as the eye and form are accomplished by pleasure, etc. Although the characteristics and functions differ, their essence is no different.
The essence of the eye that sees form is precisely that which observes itself, which also contradicts your own tenet that the sense faculties are not objects of their own kind.

Moreover, if the eye sees form in accordance with reality, the essence of form and the eye faculty is truly one. Just as it can see form, it should also see the eye faculty. Since it does not see the faculty, it should not see form.
The essence of the eye and form cannot truly differ, lest it contradict your own tenet that they are of the same nature as pleasure, etc.;
one should not say that the eye does not see in accordance with reality, lest it contradict your own tenet that it is included in direct perception.
If it is said that it sees itself, it contradicts worldly affairs.
This is also unreasonable, because substance and function are different.
If you say that the function of seeing is the same as pleasure, etc., then blue, etc. should also be invisible.

If you say that the substance of the sense organ and the object are different, then it contradicts your own doctrine that they are all of the nature of pleasure, etc., and it is impossible for a single nature to have many substances.
The same is true of transformation, because it does not leave the nature.

If you say that its substance is both different and the same, except for your clever words, who can say that the substance of the sense organ and the object are the same in one seeing, but the object is not the sense organ?
Such a doctrine is extremely difficult to believe and understand.
Just as the seeing of the eye is refuted, so are the ear, etc. The sense organ and the object are all the same in nature as pleasure, etc.

Moreover, all objects should be experienced by all sense organs, and one sense organ should experience all objects. Then the establishment of the sense organs and objects would not be possible. Therefore, one should not say that the sense organs really exist.
Next, the Ajivikas say:
Our doctrine is that the nature of the sense organs and objects is different, unlike the faults of others.
Why is this?
The five roots such as the eye are respectively the realities of fire, space, earth, water, and wind.
The eye sees three realities, namely fire, earth, and water, and also sees form.
The body feels four realities, excluding space, and also feels touch.
The ear only hears sounds, the nose only smells fragrances, and the tongue only tastes flavors.
Therefore our teacher's school is different and does not have that fault.
If so, the roots and objects are different and the same. The difference may be so, but the sameness is like that fault.
The characteristics of the eye and so forth and fire and so forth are not the same. How can the five roots have the five realities as their nature?
Earth, water, and fire are different from blue and so forth, so they are not seen by the eye.
If earth, water, fire, and wind are different from touch in substance, they should not be felt by the body.
Therefore your school also has many faults.
Moreover, that school holds that the four dharmas of the eye, form, mind, and self combine, and therefore one can see form.
This is also not so. Therefore the next verse says:
There is no form in the eye's consciousness, nor is there consciousness in form;
How can the two inner [faculties] see form when they are both absent?
The treatise says:
The two, eye and form, and the consciousness, are each separate and not two. Because they are not combined, the function of seeing does not arise.
When the three dharmas come together, they are no different from when they are separate. How can one grasp that the function of seeing arises?
There are some HÄ«nayÄna [schools] that say:
This objection is not correct. Who says that when they come together they are no different from when they are separate?
Although each of the dharmas individually has no ability, when they come together they rely on each other and have a function.
If in the state of coming together a different characteristic arises, it will be no different from before. It should not be the eye, etc.
If in the state of coming together no different characteristic arises, since it is the same as before, it should have no function of seeing.
If it is said that in the same category a different characteristic arises, this is also not correct, because it contradicts reason.
The substance of the category and the characteristic are not different. How can one say that the category is the same but the characteristic is different?
The two meanings of the same and different mutually contradict each other. To say that the substance is the same is certainly not correct.
If the three, eye, etc., generate the function of seeing, then at that time the function of seeing should also generate the three.
It is impossible for cause and effect to exist simultaneously, yet the three generate seeing, and seeing does not generate the three.
How can they be mutually cause and effect when they exist together in a single moment?
Moreover, there would be no meaning of cause and effect existing simultaneously, since the substance of the effect already exists, how could it need a cause again?

If they do not exist simultaneously, then you should admit that they exist in sequence. If they do not exist simultaneously, how can sequence be established?ğŸ”½If there is no cause at the time of the effect, of what is the effect an effect?
If there is no effect at the time of the cause, of what is the cause a cause?
If this is so, then there would be no such thing as cause and effect.
We do not even admit that they exist, much less establish their nonexistence.
Yet we speak of various causes and effects being different. This is conventional language, not the ultimate truth.
We are correcting the non-Buddhists, and incidentally correcting the Lesser Vehicle, so in this verse we only correct the eye, etc.
We have already corrected the self, so we do not discuss it again.
Just as the eyes, etc., are refuted because they combine to see forms, the ears, etc., should also be refuted according to the meaning.

Moreover, the sounds that are heard by the ears can form names and phrases to express the meaning of dharmas, which is superior to forms and other sense objects. Therefore, in this context, we carefully examine and contemplate, causing one to know that expression exists conventionally but not ultimately.
Can the sounds that are heard express meaning?
Or do they not?
If so, what is the error?
The first is not so, and therefore the next verse says:
If what is heard can express, why does it not become non-sound?
The treatise says:
The difference between what is heard and sound both can manifest meaning.
Expression is precisely what is expressed.
This shows that sound cannot express.

Even if it is allowed to be able to express, it would lose the nature of sound, because the intrinsic characteristic of sound definitely cannot express, because it is cognized by a non-discriminating consciousness, just like the other intrinsic characteristics.
Moreover, the intrinsic characteristic of sound definitely cannot express the meaning one wishes to speak of, because there is no common example, just like a unique reason.
The common characteristic of sound is not heard by the ear, because each is composed of many dharmas and has subtle parts, like non-real dharmas, etc.
If this can express meaning, it loses the nature of sound, because it is not heard, like pleasure, etc.
Apart from the nature of sound, there is nothing else that can be heard, like form, etc., because it is not the nature of sound.
The latter is also not so, therefore the next verse says:
If sound cannot express meaning, why does it give rise to understanding?
The treatise says:
If the heard sound cannot express meaning, the knowledge of names and phrases should not arise from it.
Only phrases and names can express meaning, therefore the aggregate of words is not mentioned here.
Moreover, if spoken sound cannot express meaning, it should be the same as other echoes and not the cause of the knowledge of meaning. If so, one should not understand meaning by hearing sound.

Since hearing already understands meaning, it should be able to express meaning. Isn't it that the mental consciousness, after the auditory consciousness, provisionally establishes the common characteristic based on the heard sound?

The knowledge of the meaning is elicited by the expression, and when the mental consciousness is born, both the sound and the auditory consciousness have already perished. What is the support of the common characteristic?
If the substance of the sound does not exist, what is the common characteristic?

If it is said that the power of memory recalls the previous sound, and the mind, etc., are supported by it and provisionally established as a common characteristic, then the objects of the various minds and mental activities would not be the same, and they would not be associated with the mind and not be mental activities.
If it is said that the common characteristic does not necessarily depend on sound, but is only provisionally established by the discriminating mind, how can this characteristic belong only to sound?
If it is said that it arises because of sound, are not the auditory faculty and consciousness, etc., also the cause of this?
Also, when auditory consciousness arises, it does not depend on the common characteristic. How can it be definitely established as the cause of the common characteristic?
If it is said that, having seen form, it increases, this is also the same as the doubt and cannot be taken as proof.
If it is said that the power of dharmas is difficult to conceive, then why insist on establishing a common characteristic?

If it is said that the two [cognitions] have the same basis in one sound, and that the specific characteristic is first heard by the ear and then understood by the mind together, since the sound characteristics are different, how can their substance be the same?

Since the characteristics of the mind are distinct, the substance should also be different. It is impossible for the mental consciousness to have both characteristics as its object, because memory only records the previously grasped characteristics.

If the common characteristic of sound is not due to hearing, then the specific characteristic should also not be remembered without being heard. The two can be combined as objects of cognition after being separately cognized first. Since there is no separate cognition, how can there be a combined cognition?
Therefore, the common characteristic is not a real means of expression, nor is it that sound definitely cannot convey meaning.
Although there have been extensive debates, the principle is difficult to exhaust. One should stop the digression and pursue the original meaning.
Next, the claim that sound is heard when it combines with the ear or does not combine with the ear is largely the same as the refutation of form.
Moreover, it is definitely not reasonable that sound is heard because it combines with the ear.
Therefore, the next verse says:
If sound is heard when it reaches the ear, how does one cognize the original sound?
The treatise states:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Original refers to the speaker, because the sound originates from him.
If the sound leaves the original place and reaches the ear to be heard, how can one know the person who produced the sound?

Since one understands the place of origin, the sound must not come. It should also not be said that the ear goes to the place of the sound. Since the function has no light or substance, how can one know it moves?
Moreover, the sound that expresses meaning cannot be fully understood.
Why is this?
Therefore, the next verse says:
Sound has no sudden explanation. How can it be fully understood?
The treatise says:
The subtle parts of names and phrases arise gradually, and the ear does not hear suddenly. How can it be fully understood?
It should also not be said that it is known through recollection, because recollection necessarily resembles the previous, as fully explained before. It cannot be known suddenly without recollection.
It should not be said that the mind separately knows through hearing. If so, the deaf should be able to understand sound by themselves, or the person speaking should have no use for sound.
If it is said that the power of the successive conditions of hearing leads to complete understanding, this is also not so, because the mind of complete understanding does not necessarily arise next.

If it is said that complete understanding must arise next after hearing, this is also not so, because after the heavenly ear supernormal power, one must be separated from the mind of concentration in order to have complete understanding.
Moreover, the other mental consciousness, after hearing a sound, also takes many moments before it has complete understanding.
It cannot be maintained that there is a real expressive sound that the ear can first hear and the mind can later understand.
It is merely the mind of false discrimination that manifests the sounds of speech and takes them to be expressive.
Next, one should carefully investigate what is meant by sound and name.
Its substance is real and is what is heard by the ear.
If that is not so,
Then the next verse says:
Up to what is not heard, should not be the nature of sound;
The principle of being nonexistent before and existing later is definitely not appropriate.
The treatise says:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The substance of future sound is not audible to the ear, because the five sense organs such as the eye apprehend present objects.
Then future sound should not be the nature of sound, because it is not audible, just like the sense objects such as form.
If future sound is of the same kind as the present, because the present is audible,
then the present sound should also be of the same kind as the future, and because the future is not sound, the present should also not be sound.
Moreover, flowing from the future into the present, the present can be said to be not sound based on that.
But the future does not flow from the present, so how can the present be said to be sound based on that?

If what is audible in the present is the nature of sound, then this nature of sound should originally be non-existent and then arise, which contradicts your doctrine that the nature of sound existed before.
If the nature of sound existed before, it should not be newly arisen;
since it is not newly arisen, it should not cease later;
without arising and without ceasing, the nature of sound should be eternal.
Moreover, past sound should not be the nature of sound, because it is not audible, just like future sound.
If sound that is not yet present enters the present, and the present is sound, then it should be said that present sound enters the past.
Because the past is not sound, the present is also not sound.
If so, then the nature of sound in the three times should be established in mutual dependence, and all are not real sound.

Moreover, if present sound is said to be born by coming from the future, then past sound should also be said to be born by coming from the present, and then past sound should be called present, and should cease later.

If past sound is said to cease by coming from the present, then present sound should also be said to cease by coming from the future, and then present sound should be called past, and should not cease later.
The future, which has neither, should be said to be permanent. That which has cessation and birth should be called past or present.
In this way, the nature of sound is dispersed and destroyed. Form and so forth are also like this. One should consider it in accordance with reason.
Next, there is a SÄá¹ƒkhya who makes this assertion:
The mind goes to the place of the object in order to cognize it.
This is also the same as the refutation of the sense organ going to the object mentioned above.
Moreover, one should not say that the mind, apart from the sense organ, is able to cognize objects by itself. Therefore, the next verse says:
If the mind is apart from the sense organs, going would also be useless.
The treatise says:
If the mind is definitely unable to cognize forms and other phenomena apart from the sense organs, going would also be pointless.

If the mind alone cognizes objects without depending on the sense organs, then the blind and deaf and others should be able to cognize all objects, or else there should be no such categories as the blind and deaf.
This has already been discussed previously and need not be repeated.
Moreover, when the sense organs are nourished, the mind becomes clear and sharp. Therefore, the mind definitely does not leave the sense organs.
There are those who hold that the essence of the inner mind is all-pervading, and its functions depend on each individual sense organ to go to the objects that are cognized.
The function is precisely the mind manifesting the aspects of cognizing objects. When it arises, it cognizes objects. What need is there for it to go again?
One cannot hold that there is a separate manifestation and a separate cognition, lest the manifestation of forms and so forth cognize the objects of sounds and so forth.
Moreover, the mind should not leave its function to go to the object. If you hold that the substance is omnipresent, to what place does the function go?
Moreover, it should not be so. Therefore the next verse says:
If the person is like this, it should always be without mind.
The treatise says:
If the mind goes to the object, the substance is not omnipresent.
If the mind always goes to the object, I should be without mind.

However, the subtle mind always exists in the body, constantly functioning in states of sleep, stupor, etc., because there is breathing, etc., because it can be obtained in dreams, because fatigue increases, because it induces the awakened mind, because it supports the body, and because it touches the body and is aware.
Moreover, if the internal body always lacks mind, then harming it should not be a fault, and offering to it should not be a merit, which would be the same as the nihilistic view of non-Buddhists.

There are those who hold that the substance of the mind is not omnipresent and does not function, but the function has activity. This also has the same fault, because the mind and its substance are not separate.

Moreover, if the mind's substance goes to the objects in front, there would be contact with the inner body, and there should be no feeling of awareness, and one should diligently contemplate without harming the inner mind.

If one grasps that the mind is not united with its own object, it should be like other objects and also unable to know, and each mind should know all objects, or each object should be known by all minds.
Thus, all the schools that grasp real faculties and objects are unreasonable, and one should believe that they are not true.
Isn't the same fault committed by the Great Vehicle?
Even if a little reality is admitted, this fault should be the same.
If so, there should be no worldly affairs, because of the inversion of thought.
That is to say, if they are not without thought, what is it that causes inversion, making one think that worldly affairs exist and are not non-existent?
Thought refers to the aggregate of thought. Therefore, the next verse says:
Causing the mind to falsely grasp objects, relying on past seeing like a mirage,
Falsely establishing the meaning of dharmas, this should be known as the aggregate of thought.
The treatise says:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

When the mind first arises, it grasps the characteristics of blue, etc., just as one sets up a sign to remember later. It grasps characteristics that transcend the objects of the sense organs, and is therefore called conceptualization.
Because of this conceptualization, one is able to clearly remember the characteristics of an object at a later time.

Although all minds have conceptualization, conceptualization is superior in the fruition stage, and therefore it is said to be based on what existed previously, because what is manifest in the later stage was already present in the earlier stage.

This conceptualization falsely establishes the characteristics of dharmas and their meanings, whether sentient or nonsentient, in the entire world, just as the idea of water arises in dependence on a mirage, deceiving one's own mind and also causing others to speak of it. Because of this conceptualization, the various distinctions of sense bases, sense objects, and other worldly things are established.

In order to show that this conceptualization is established in dependence on many dharmas and is therefore a provisional reality and not a true reality, it is said to be the aggregate of conceptualization.
It is also said that one should know that the distinctions of dharmas and their meanings in the world are all established by conceptualization.
Aren't the five consciousnesses conditioned by real sense objects?
The mental consciousness that accompanies the five consciousnesses is also like this.
The objects of thought and the various consciousnesses must be the same. How can it be said with certainty that thought is inverted?
Who says that the consciousnesses take real, existent objects as their objects and mistakenly raise objections?
Therefore, the next verse says:
The eye, form, and so forth are the conditions, giving rise to consciousnesses like illusions.
The treatise says:
Although the substance of various illusory phenomena is actually nonexistent, it can give rise to various false consciousnesses.

The eye and so forth are also like this. Their substance and characteristics are all empty. Like a deceptive person giving rise to false consciousnesses in others, thought arises in accordance with this. How can the object be real?
The faculties and objects are both empty, as extensively explained before.

The consciousnesses that arise from this are also not real. What appears is all false, just like illusory phenomena. The substance of consciousness is not the objects that appear, lest it be the same as those objects and consciousness be without cognitive activity. It is also not separate from objects with a separate substance of consciousness, because apart from the appearing objects, the characteristics of consciousness do not exist. How can it be said that the substance of consciousness truly exists?
There is a verse that says:
Those able to cognize various consciousnesses are not the same as the appearing objects,
And are also not apart from those objects, therefore there are no characteristics to grasp.

Some say that magical illusions are all real and not false, the power of spells and incantations adds to wood, stone, etc., causing them to appear similar to the characteristics of carriages, horses, etc., the substance of these characteristics either uses sound, etc. as its essence, or its substance is precisely a part of consciousness.
In order to refute their rescue, the next verse says:
If one grasps as truly existent, the illusion analogy would not be established.
The treatise says:
If the illusion is real, with sound, etc. as its essence, like the rest of sound, etc., it should not be called an illusion.
If it is said that the magical illusion quickly moves without stopping, like what is created by transformation, therefore it is called an illusion.
This is also not so, since the substance already truly exists, like the rest of sound, etc., why not call it real?
Quickly moving without stopping is also not the characteristic of an illusion, do not let lightning flashes, etc. also obtain the name of illusion.
If you say that it is called an illusion because it deceives the world, the characteristics of an illusion are not false, so how can it be said to deceive?
If you say that it is called an illusion because it produces errors such as permanence, then other dharmas should also be called illusions.
Also, you should not say that an illusion is a part of consciousness, because it is not the nature of understanding. How can it be the mind?
Or you should use a different name to express the meaning of consciousness only. You should believe that all dharmas are not apart from mind. How can one mind really have many parts?
Or you should believe and accept that the substance of consciousness is not real. If consciousness is real and has many parts, then the substance of all dharmas would be the same.
If the substance of consciousness is one but it manifests two parts, like the appearance of water in a mirage, then you should not say that an illusion is a part of consciousness.
Its substance is really existent, because consciousness is not dual. How can the part of the substance of consciousness be many?
If that is so, what does the Mahayana teach is an illusion?
The illusion I speak of is like what is commonly known in the world.
When wisdom investigates the nature of illusory phenomena, it cannot be found. How can words describe it?
Therefore, all dharmas are like illusions. There is not even the slightest reality to be found within them.
As a verse says:
When wisdom investigates, the nature of dharmas is non-existent.
Therefore, it is said to be natureless. It cannot be described by conceptual proliferation.
Therefore, dharmas arise from causes and conditions. Their nature is all empty, just like illusions.
If the nature of dharmas is empty but appears to exist, how is it different from a lasso encircling and binding empty space?
The principle of the nature of dharmas is so. Why are you surprised?
The affairs of the world are difficult to fathom. There are truly many such cases. To verify these words, the next verse says:ğŸ”½In the world, all that exists
is difficult to fathom.
The principle of faculties and objects is the same. Why would the wise be surprised?
The treatise says:

It is like a single thought of karma that can attract the boundless internal and external fruits of the future, with distinctions in form, which even the most skilled craftsmen cannot create. This is called the first difficulty to fathom in the world.

Moreover, it is like external seeds producing sprouts, stems, countless branches, flowers, leaves, roots, and fruits, with forms and colors intricately arranged, vividly beautiful. This is called the second difficulty to fathom in the world.

Moreover, it is like a prostitute's body, which seems like a cesspool constantly flowing with various impurities, yet those with lust see it and give rise to sexual thoughts. This is called the third difficulty to fathom in the world.

Moreover, it is like a flower tree called no worries. When a prostitute touches it, the flowers all bloom and the branches sway as if with love. This is called the fourth difficulty to fathom in the world.

Moreover, it is like a flower tree called pleasurable sound. When it hears the sound of music, the entire tree shakes, with the branches swaying like a dancing person. This is called the fifth difficulty to fathom in the world.

It is also like a flower tree called beautiful bird singing. When hearing the bird singing, it immediately shakes, with its branches swaying like a person joyfully applauding. This is called the sixth difficult-to-understand thing in the world.

It is also like being born in the upper realms for immeasurable lives, and when regressing to be born in the lower realms, immediately seeking the mother's milk, leaping and playing, eating and sleeping with greed for sex. This is called the seventh difficult-to-understand thing in the world.

It is also like delighting in unsurpassed enlightenment, diligently cultivating subtle wholesome dharmas, yet acting with negligence, denying all dharmas. This is called the eighth difficult-to-understand thing in the world.

It is also like abandoning the cramped household life, going to the place of enlightenment, yet engaging in worldly affairs, greedily attached to wealth and sex with no remorse or shame. This is called the ninth difficult-to-understand thing in the world.

It is also like the supernormal powers produced by pure concentration, with wondrous functions boundless and unobstructed, all accomplished according to one's wishes. This is called the tenth difficult-to-understand thing in the world.

Thus, the difficulties of measuring worldly phenomena are boundless. The existence or non-existence of sense faculties and objects is extremely easy to understand. Conventionally, they exist; ultimately, they are empty.
The wise should not be surprised by this.
In order to show that phenomena are conventionally existent and ultimately empty, a verse is again spoken at the end of this chapter:
All phenomena are like a whirling fire wheel, magical transformations, dreams, and illusions,
Water moons, comets, echoes, mirages, and floating clouds.
The treatise states:
Like a whirling fire wheel, magical transformations, dreams, etc., although appearing to exist, are all actually empty.

All phenomena are also like this. Foolish people falsely grasp and discriminate, thinking they exist, but their essence is actually non-existent. When apart from false grasping, there is nothing seen at all.
Like one with clear eyes not seeing flowers in the sky, the seeing of the unconditioned holy wisdom is true. Because the subject, object, and mode of activity are extinguished.
Thus, it accords well with the sutra's statement that the activities of the conditioned consciousness mind are not real.
Therefore, faculties and objects are all conventional, not real, because they are the objects of consciousness, like a fire wheel and so forth.

The views of non-Buddhists are not real, because they grasp existence and non-existence like those with blurred vision and so forth. If one wishes to seek holy wisdom, eliminate delusion and accord with reality, one should follow the TathÄgata's perfect and pure Dharma teachings.
